questions.question: Which immunologic abnormalities are observed in the local milieu of sarcoid granulomas?

options.A: Accumulation of CD8+ T cells and increased CD8/CD4 T-cell ratio
options.C: Increased levels of Th1 cytokines such as IL-4 and IL-10
options.D: Accumulation of CD4+ T cells and increased CD4/CD8 T-cell ratios

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Accumulation of CD4+ T cells and increased CD4/CD8 T-cell ratios Sarcoid granulomas exhibit an accumulation of CD4+ T cells, with CD4/CD8 T-cell ratios ranging from 5: 1 to 15: 1. Several immunologic abnormalities in the local milieu of sarcoid granulomas suggest a cell-mediated immune response to an unidentified antigen. These abnormalities include: Intra-alveolar and interstitial accumulation of CD4+ T cells, resulting in CD4/CD8 T-cell ratios ranging from 5: 1 to 15: 1, suggesting pathogenic involvement of CD4+ helper T cells. (Option A) There is an oligoclonal expansion of T-cell subsets (Option B) Increased T cell-derived Th1 cytokines such as IL-2 and interferon (IFN)- γ may be responsible for T-cell expansion and macrophage activation, respectively. (Option C) Several cytokines (IL-8, TNF, macrophage inflammatory protein) are increased in the local environment. TNF released by macrophages in the bronchoalveolar fluid is a marker of disease activity. Systemically, there is anergy to skin test antigens and polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 696

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with fever, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, erythema nodosum, and acute polyarthritis affecting ankles and knees. He has a history of recurrent uveitis. Laboratory tests show elevated serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels and hypercalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lofgren's syndrome Explanation : This patient's clinical presentation and lab findings are suggestive of Lofgren’s syndrome which is associated with sarcoidosis. A history of uveitis, elevated levels of serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), which is a marker of granulomatous activity, and hypercalcemia (increased activation of vitamin D by macrophages within granulomas) all point to systemic involvement and suggest sarcoidosis. Lofgren syndrome triad: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy Acute polyarthritis Erythema nodosum - tender, red nodules on the skin, typically on the shins (as shown in the image) Lupus pernio (Option A): Cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis characterised by violaceous or erythematous indurated plaques distributed on the central face, particularly the nose and cheeks. Mikulicz syndrome (Option C): Defined as diffuse and bilateral enlargement of the salivary and lacrimal glands. It can occur as an isolated phenomenon or as a part of systemic diseases like sarcoidosis, Sjögren syndrome, etc. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Option D): Autoimmune disease affecting multiple organs, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and heart. Common symptoms of SLE include joint pain, skin rash (such as the classic butterfly rash), fatigue, and organ involvement.

questions.question: In a histopathological examination of a lung biopsy from a patient with suspected sarcoidosis, which of the following microscopic features would be most characteristic and supportive of the diagnosis?

options.A: Macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment
options.B: Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies (stellate-shaped structures) and Schaumann bodies (calcium and protein inclusions). Asteroid Bodies: Asteroid bodies are stellate or star-shaped structures seen within the cytoplasm of giant cells. They are composed of aggregated proteinaceous material consisting primarily of fibrin. The image below shows asteroid bodies. Schaumann Bodies: They are concentrically laminated, basophilic structures found within the cytoplasm of giant cells. They comprise calcium and proteinaceous material, such as mucopolysaccharides and immunoglobulins. Macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment (smokers’ macrophages) (Option A) are seen in desquamative interstitial pneumonia and respiratory bronchiolitis–associated interstitial lung disease. Coalescent tubercles with central caseation (Option C) are seen in active lesions of secondary tuberculosis. Curschmann spirals (extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous glands) and Charcot-Leyden crystals (composed of the eosinophil-derived protein) (Option D) are characteristic findings in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimens of patients with atopic asthma.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with a chronic cough, dyspnea, and chest tightness. On examination, fine crackles are heard bilaterally. A lung biopsy reveals collections of carbon-laden macrophages within the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts, along with focal fibrosis and occasional small granulomas. Which of the following is not a condition associated with this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Psittacosis Explanation: As the histopathology shows carbon-laden macrophages, it is not associated with Psittacosis which is a zoonotic bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia psittaci, contracted from exposure to infected birds, such as parrots. Carbon deposits are dark black and are readily visible grossly and microscopically. Inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages, accumulating in the connective tissue adjacent to the lymphatics and organised lymphoid tissue adjacent to the bronchi or lung hilum. Anthracosis (Option A) is the deposition of carbon particles in the lungs due to chronic inhalation of smoke, soot, or pollution. It is commonly seen in urban dwellers, smokers, and coal workers. HPE shows carbon-laden macrophages. Coal Worker’s P neumoconiosis (CWP) Simple CWP (Option B) Complicated CWP (Option C) It is characterised by coal macules (1 to 2 mm in diameter) and larger coal nodules containing carbon-laden macrophages and a delicate network of collagen fibres. Although these lesions are scattered throughout the lung, the upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes are more heavily involved. Dilatation of alveoli adjacent to bronchioles gives rise to centrilobular emphysema. It leads to progressive massive fibrosis and large, dark scars measuring 1 to 10 cm in diameter, often appearing in multiple areas. Microscopically, these lesions contain dense collagen and pigment deposition. Lung function is compromised Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 692 Psittacosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 50-year-old sandblaster presents with chronic cough, dyspnea, and chest pain. Further investigation reveals a history of prolonged exposure to sandblasting. He has also worked for several years in mines, where he was exposed to chronic asbestos and beryllium. A chest X-ray was taken, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Silicosis Explanation : The chest X-ray shows calcification of hilar lymph nodes, called eggshell calcification. The clinical picture, along with eggshell calcification, suggests silicosis. Silicosis: It is the most prevalent occupational lung disease in the world. Cause: Inhalation of proinflammatory crystalline silicon dioxide (silica). After decades of exposure, it usually presents as slowly progressing, nodular, fibrosing pneumoconiosis. questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of eggshell calcification?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Metastatic lymph nodes. Explanation: Eggshell calcification is not seen in metastatic lymph nodes. Eggshell calcification refers to a ring of calcification at the periphery of a lymph node (thin sheets of calcification in lymph nodes; calcium surrounding a zone lacking calcification). Causes: Silicosis (Option A) Coal workers pneumoconiosis Sarcoidosis (Option B) Post-radiotherapy (Option C) Post-irradiation lymphoma Tuberculosis Amyloidosis Histoplasmosis Blastomycosis

questions.question: Which of the following forms of asbestos is more toxic?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Amphibole Explanation: Amphibole (crocidolite, amosite) is the most toxic form of asbestos. Asbestos is a family of crystalline hydrated silicates associated with pulmonary fibrosis and various forms of cancer. It occurs in two distinct geometric forms: serpentine and amphibole. Amphiboles are straight and stiffly aligned with the airstream and can be delivered deeper into the lungs. They can penetrate epithelial cells and reach the interstitium. Chrysolites, with their more flexible, curled structure, are likely to become impacted in the upper respiratory passages and removed by the mucociliary elevator. Even if they get trapped in the lungs, they are easily removed as they are more soluble. Both amphiboles and serpentines are fibrogenic and are associated with a higher incidence of asbestos-related diseases. Serpentine/ Chrysolite Amphibole/ Crocidolite/ Amosite Wavy Rigid More common (90% of the asbestos) More pathogenic (amphiboles particularly associated with mesothelioma ) Mnemonic: I am crying (Chrysotile) After looking at a snake (Serpentine) Snake is wavy Snakes can be seen more commonly (more common) Mnemonic: I am on a site (Amosite) Saw a Crocodile (Crocidolite) Which is an Amphibian Crocodile is straight (rigid) Erionite is a naturally occurring fibrous mineral with properties similar to asbestos. Exposure to it is associated with increased risks of lung cancer and mesothelioma. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 694

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent chest pain, shortness of breath, and unexplained weight loss. He was chronically exposed to minerals when he worked as a shipbuilder. Imaging studies revealed a growth that was subjected to needle biopsy. What is the most common lung malignancy associated with his occupational exposure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Adenocarcinoma Explanation: The patient's occupational history where he worked as a Shipbuilder suggests that he was chronically exposed to Asbestos and the most common lung malignancy seen with occupational asbestos exposure is adenocarcinoma. Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung and pleural cancers. Asbestos-related lung carcinoma is markedly magnified by smoking. Thus, asbestos workers (particularly those who smoke) are at much higher risk of dying of lung carcinoma than mesothelioma. Compared to other occupational lung diseases which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes. Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma ) is the most common type of cancer that accounts for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma. (Option A) Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma. (Option C) In contrast to bronchogenic carcinoma, the risk of mesothelioma does not increase with smoking in patients with asbestos.

questions.question: Match the following occupational lung diseases with their characteristics. A) Byssinosis 1. Iron exposure B) Bagassosis 2. Monday disease C) Siderosis 3. Non-caseating granuloma. D) Berylliosis 4. Sugarcane dust exposure
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : B) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3 A. Byssinosis 2. Monday disease B. Bagassosis 4. Sugarcane dust exposure C. Siderosis 1. Iron exposure D. Berylliosis 3. Non-caseating granuloma. Explanation : Byssinosis: Cotton dust/ organic dust exposure. The patient usually complains that the symptoms worsen when they come to work on Monday, hence the name Monday disease. They get better when off work, and symptoms reduce as the week progresses. This cycle is repeated. Bagassosis is caused by inhaling the fibrous cane-sugar residue called bagasse. It occurs in those working with bagasse, such as those in wallboard or paper manufacturing, but is not seen in sugar industry workers. Siderosis is due to exposure to iron oxide in welders. Berylliosis is caused by beryllium exposure. It leads to non-caseating granulomas, as in sarcoidosis and can be differentiated based on industry exposure. Stannosis - Tin/ Lead exposure. Baritosis - Barium exposure. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 692 Byssinosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Bagassosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about mesothelioma?

options.A: Most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure

questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Leads to mediastinal shift Explanation: Mesothelioma A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura. It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis. Aetiology Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer (Option A) It is not associated with smoking (Option D) Pathology Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile. Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis. The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma. M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p , leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene- CDKN2A. Clinical features Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis. Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening). Diagnosis CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion) (Options C and D) Confirmed by biopsy: Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma. Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns. Specific markers for mesothelioma: Calretinin. Epithelial membrane antigen. Cytokeratin. Mesothelin. Prognosis Poor (median survival of 9-21 months). Mesothelioma- Gross Mesothelioma- H & E stain Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain Lobulated pleural soft tissue mass encasing the right lung. Associated erosion of the right 3rd rib anteriorly. Calcified pleural plaques were noted bilaterally, indicating previous asbestos exposure. Mesothelioma - sarcomatoid.
